dialogues.text: MICHAEL is lying in a single bed, his face violently inflamed. CARLA is with the DOCTOR, a much older man.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Come in.  INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY The flat is without decoration, an enfilade of small room stove, a sink, a tub, a boiler, a table, a few wooden cha There is no window, just a balcony door to let light into room. HANNA carries on ironing.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL

dialogues.text: You're better now?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Have you always been weak?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh no. I’d never been ill before. It’s incredibly boring. There's nothing to do. I couldn’t even be bothered to read. HANNA carries on ironing. He is becoming as comfortable w the silence as she is. She starts ironing a pair of knick He watches her bare arms moving back and forth. She looks broad-planed, strong. dialogues.text: The doctor told me I had to take walks.

dialogues.text: HANNA has fallen asleep on MICHAEL'S chest. He is awake, looking at the birthmark on her left shoulder. The sound the wood yard below. He kisses the birthmark. She stirs.

dialogues.text: What’s your name? She opens her eyes. A look of suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Your name.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Why do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’ve been here three times. You haven’t told me your name.  12. MICHAEL waits a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Michael.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Michael. Hmm. So I’m with a Michael. HANNA smiles, as if there were something funny about it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: ‘Hanna’.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: You never tell me what you've been studying.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Studying?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: At school. Do you learn languages?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh... MICHAEL thinks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Quo, quo scelesti ruitis? Aut cur dexteris aptantur enses conditi? MICHAEL smiles slightly.

dialogues.text: It’s Horace.

dialogues.text: What about in German?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Do you have anything?

dialogues.text: Well, I’m writing an essay. It’s about a play. By a writer called Gotthold Ephraim Lessing. Perhaps you've heard of him? HANNA makes no reaction.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Have you got it? MICHAEL reaches down to the satchel and pulls out a book.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Here. You can read it.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I’d rather listen to you. There is a silence as MICHAEL absorbs the idea.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL

dialogues.text: HANNA has gone in to put down her things at the kitchen table. MICHAEL follows, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I got up - at 4.30 - specially - it’s the first day of the holidays, I’d been planning to surprise you -

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Poor little baby. Got up at four thirty - and on your holidays too.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What is this? I was on your tram! You totally ignored me! What do you think I was doing? Why the hell do you think I was there? MICHAEL has yelled in desperation. HANNA looks him straig in the eye.  17.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I haven't the slightest idea. And what you do is your business not mine. HANNA turns and moves away.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: And if you wanted to speak to me, I was in the first carriage. So why did you sit in the second? HANNA goes to run a bath.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: And now, thanks very much, I've been working, I need a bath. Get out, I’d like to be by myself.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL

He sits by himself, miserable. He hears her, bathing. Then finally gets up an goes back in. She is still in the bath.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to say. I’ve never been with a woman. We’ve been together four weeks and I can’t live without you. I can’t. Even the thought of it kills me. HANNA looks at him thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I sat in the second carriage because I thought you might kiss me.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Is it true what you said? That I don’t matter to you? In the bath, she shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Do you have a book?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh. Well I do. I took something with me this morning.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s another play. MICHAEL gets it out of his pocket. HANNA has lain down on bed, completely content.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: We're changing the order we do things. Read to me first, kid. Then we make love. MICHAEL sits at the foot of the bed and starts to read.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Intrigue and Love, a play by Friedrich Schiller... INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY HANNA is baking bread. MICHAEL is on a chair beside her w a book.  He starts 19.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: The Odyssey by Homer.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: What’s an odyssey?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s a journey. He sets out on a journey. to read.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: “Sing to me of the Man, Muse, the man of twists and turns Driven time and again off course, once he had plundered The hallowed heights of Troy. Many cities of men he saw and learned their minds, Many pains he suffered, heartsick at the open sea, Fighting to save his life and bring his comrades home... INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. EVE HANNA is in the bath. MICHAEL is reading a Shakespeare so to her. She pulls

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: “And we will some new pleasures prove of golden sands and crystal brooks, with silken lights and silver hooks...”

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Come here. him into the bath. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. NIGHT HANNA is sewing. MICHAEL is reading Huckleberry Finn.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I poked into the place aways and encountered a little open patch as big as a bedroom, all hung around with vines and found a man lying there asleep, and by Jinks it was my old Jim...  20. He starts acting out Jim, and the two of them collapse laughing. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY MICHAEL is at the bottom of the bed. HANNA is lying insid He is reading Lady Chatterley’s Lover.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: “Lady Chatterley felt his naked flesh against her as he came into her. For a moment he was still inside her...

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: This is disgusting. Where did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I borrowed it from someone at school.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: You should be ashamed. Go on. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. EVE MICHAEL reads Tin-Tin to HANNA, who is lying on the bed. are both looking at the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: ‘Blistering Barnacles and a thundering typhoon. It is water.’ ‘But what on earth did you expect it to be?’

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Whisky.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Whisky! By thunder, whisky. ‘Whisky? Come now captain, you can’t be serious.’

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: All right, kid, that’s enough for today. They fall back onto the bed.  21.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I was wondering, do you think you could get some time off? Maybe we could go for a trip.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: What sort of trip?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’d love to go bicycling. Just for two days. MICHAEL reaches for a book.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’ve got a guide-book. I’ve worked out the route. Look, what do you think? HANNA’S look is so far-away she doesn’t seem to hear the question. Silence. Then :

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I think you like planning, don’t you? She throws the book away and they begin to make love.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. BERG APARTMENT. DAWN
dialogues.text: First light. Dawn breaking outside the window. MICHAEL is working at his desk, the surface covered in stamps, his collection book open. He picks one with a pyramid on it a looks at it. Underneath, MICHAEL'S VOICE reading Intrigue Love by Schiller.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: “I'm not frightened. I’m not frightened of anything. Why should I be? I welcome obstacles, because they’1l be like mountains I can fly over to be in your arms. The more I suffer, the more I’1l love...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Seen from outside, a shop full of stamps. MICHAEL and a S DEALER with white hair and a moustache. MICHAEL is offeri his pyramid stamp, his gestures becoming desperate as the STAMP DEALER shakes his head, clearly not giving him as m as he hopes.  22. Then MICHAEL concedes, the DEALER concedes, and a bunch o notes are handed across. MICHAEL runs exhilarated out int the street.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: “Danger will only increase my love, it will sharpen it, it will give it spice. I’ll be the only angel you need. On this arm, Luise, you will go dancing through life. You will leave life even more beautiful than you entered it. Heaven will take you back and look at you and say ‘Only one thing can make a soul complete, and that thing is love.’

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HILL. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA and MICHAEL are whizzing down a hill together on bicycles. He has a rucksack. It’s a rural paradise - hill all sides, a gleaming river below, the sun shining bright She is wearing a blue dress.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAFE. DAY
dialogues.text: They come to a cafe and sit down outside. They pick up th menus on the table. A WAITRESS arrives.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: So what would you like to have?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What are you having?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: You order. I'll have what you have. MICHAEL starts giving the order. Next to them are a group BOY SCOUTS, who are laughing among themselves.

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: There’s sausages, sausages or sausages. Give it to me, come on, give it here. Let me have a look. You always have the same thing. They all laugh. HANNA watches them nervously.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAFE. DAY
dialogues.text: The meal finished, MICHAEL is alone, paying the bill.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: I hope your mother was happy.  23.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. She enjoyed her meal very much. The WAITRESS goes. HANNA returns from inside. MICHAEL hol out his arm to her, which she takes. They walk away towar their bikes. He is smiling. MICHAEL looks round, then dar to reach across and kiss her on the lips. The WAITRESS watches.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHURCH. DAY
dialogues.text: They get off their bikes at a small church. MICHAEL stops gets out a map and a guide book.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Here, let me show you where we’re going.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: It’s OK, kid. I don’t want to know. The sound of a choir from inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHURCH. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL and HANNA enter tentatively to find a choir rehearsing Bach. It is a traditional German scene - whole families singing together at the altar. HANNA is transpor entranced at the sound of the music. MICHAEL watches.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIVERSIDE. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA is in a river, the water up to her calves, her skir tied round her thighs. She is completely absorbed. Then s looks up, aware of being watched. MICHAEL is sitting with notebook.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m writing a poem. About you.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Can I hear it?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s not ready. I'll read it to you one day.  24.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MICHAEL'S APARTMENT. BERLIN. DAY
dialogues.text: 1995. MICHAEL, now 51, is standing by his desk. He opens drawer. He takes out the recognizable notebook. He opens yellowing pages and looks at the poetry. Then flips the pages, to some handwritten lists - the words ‘Odyssey’, ‘Schnitzler’, ‘Chekhov’, ‘Zweig’ with numbers beside them MICHAEL flaps it shut, puts it back and turns to go out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL leaves his apartment block. He gets into his blac Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is listening on the radio to the same Bach music heard in the church. He drives through the thriving moder city. Beyond, the huge cranes and gouged-out building sit of a city under construction.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL swings his car into place. He gets out and heads across the road, prosperous, purposeful.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOBBY. COURTHOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: An ASSISTANT meets MICHAEL with his robe which he pulls o he walks quickly through an elaborate lobby. GERHARD BADE also in his fifties, also robed, falls in step.

dialogues.speaker: GERHARD
dialogues.text: You all right, Michael?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: GERHARD
dialogues.text: You'd better hurry. You know what she’s like. A robed ASSISTANT is waiting outside the door with docume he hands to MICHAEL. They all go in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURTROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL joins his CLIENT, just seconds before the FEMALE JUDGE comes in and everyone stands. Silence. The JUDGE lo at MICHAEL disapprovingly, sensing his lateness. Everyone sits. MICHAEL sits, thinking back.  25.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STAIRWAY. SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: 1958. A sheriff's posse of sixteen-year old GIRLS, come laughing, blushing towards the classroom. One of them is talking excitedly to the other.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m just going to pretend I’ve been here for years, I’m not going to behave in any special way.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You just wait. You wait and see. They smile together and head for the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: The BOYS are already in place, dotted round, as the GIRLS come in. There are cries of ‘Here they come’. Then the TEACHER comes in.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Good morning, ladies. Gentlemen, please welcome your new fellow- students, treat them with courtesy, please. Not far from MICHAEL, a GIRL sits across the aisle, virgi with brown hair, brown summer skin.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Hello. My name’s Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m Michael. The TEACHER comes in. The class quietens.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: Later. The TEACHER is in full flow. MICHAEL can’t take hi eyes off SOPHIE.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Everyone believes that Homer’s subject is homecoming. In fact, The Odyssey is a book about a journey. Home is a place you dream of, it’s not a place you ever attain. The TEACHER breaks off.  26.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Berg, I don’t mean to distract you, but we’re meant to studying Homer, not studying Sophia. The whole class cracks up. MICHAEL blushes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWIMMING LAKE. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is riveted as SOPHIE swims fast and lithe through water. Around him, YOUNG PEOPLE are lounging round on tow It’s the social centre. HOLGER and RUDOLF are rubbing the hair with towels as SOPHIE approaches.

dialogues.speaker: HOLGER
dialogues.text: Michael the water’s fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s wonderful, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: HOLGER
dialogues.text: Wonderful. It’s going to be a great summer. MICHAEL looks across to where a group of AMERICANS are shouting and playing a very loud game of volleyball.

dialogues.speaker: HOLGER
dialogues.text: Now the Americans have allowed us back in our own lake.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Why are they so loud?

dialogues.speaker: HOLGER
dialogues.text: You should see their stores. They have everything.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh sure. Everything mankind could ever dream of.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You don’t like Americans?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Just it’s more fun without them. He looks SOPHIE straight in the eye. There is a sudden silence, MICHAEL looking straight at SOPHIE. SOPHIE looks down. Then MICHAEL moves slightly to pack up his stuff.  27.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Why do you leave early?

dialogues.speaker: HOLGER
dialogues.text: He always leaves early.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BANHOFSTRASSE. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is cycling back towards town, a smile on his face

dialogues.speaker: INT. HANNA'S APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL flies up the stairs, then goes in. HANNA is sitti sewing. He kisses her on the cheek as he gets out a book.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I’m late. I was held up at school. At once he sits down opposite her. A ritual.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: The Lady with the Little Dog. By Anton Chekhov. HANNA looks, seeing right through him.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: “The talk was that a new face had appeared on the promenade, a lady with a little dog.”

dialogues.speaker: INT. GARAGE. DAY
dialogues.text: A huge tram-shed full of empty trams. HANNA is at the end the garage, talking to the SUPERVISER, a large man in his fifties.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERVISER
dialogues.text: Schmitz, one moment. We’ve got good news for you. Your work is good, we're going to promote you. To work with me in the office. It’s more money. Congratulations. He moves away. HANNA looks distraught.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWIMMING LAKE. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is watching SOPHIE swimming, a look of anxiety in eye, when HOLGER touches his shoulder.  28.

dialogues.speaker: HOLGER
dialogues.text: Get a move on, we’re leaving early today.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Why? What for?

dialogues.speaker: HOLGER
dialogues.text: We're going back to Sophie's. It’s your birthday. We’re giving you a party. HOLGER and RUDOLF disappear to get dressed. SOPHIE appear her swimming costume.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Come on, it’s a surprise. We thought you’d like it. We’ve been planning it for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Really. I promised someone I’d do something else. The others are furious with him. They all go off.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is cycling towards HANNA’S apartment, his hair we from the lake, looking equally unhappy. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY HANNA is sitting unhappily as MICHAEL reads to her. They both in a bad mood.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Oh kid, kid. Stop.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Nothing’s wrong. It’s nothing. HANNA just shrugs. She goes and sits at the table to drin tea. MICHAEL is irritated.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You never ask, you never bother to ask how I am.  29.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: You never say.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It just happens to be my birthday. It’s my birthday, that’s all. In fact, you've never even asked when it is.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Look if you want a fight, kid...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No, I don’t want a fight. What’s wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: What business is it of yours? She has snapped at him, razor-like.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s always on your terms. Everything. We do what you want. It’s always what you want. My friends were giving me a party!

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Well then why are you here? Go back to your party. Isn’t that what you want? HANNA puts down her cup, angry. She goes into the bedroom slams the door. He sits, the magic of the day gone. He ge up and opens the bedroom door. HANNA is on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: And it’s always me that has to apologize. Silence. HANNA lets time go by. Then

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: You don’t have to apologize. No-one has to apologize. No-one can make you. HANNA reaches for a book from beside the bed. She throws down on the cover.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: War and Peace, kid.  30. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY HANNA is on the edge of the bath, running water. She has pale blue flowered smock. She is running with sweat. The smock sticks to her. MICHAEL gets out a book. HANNA drops lavender oil into the bath. MICHAEL stands in the bath an she washes his body. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY They are making love on the bed. It’s intense. At one poi she moves on top of him. She holds his head between her hands, as if she would crush the life out of him. Then sh lets go.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HANNA'S APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: They are both sweating, exhausted. She looks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Now you must go back to your friends. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY MICHAEL has gone. HANNA washes out milk bottles and empti them into the sink. Then she picks up her luggage and lea the empty apartment.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWIMMING LAKE. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is sitting on the pier watching as HOLGER, RUDOLF SOPHIE swim competitively out to a pontoon, then turn bac full of energy and high spirits. MICHAEL watches for a wh then suddenly he gets up and starts to run away from them all.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Michael. You all right? But MICHAEL is running away across the lakeside beach. INT. LANDING & HANNA’S APARTMENT. DUSK MICHAEL opens the door. He goes in. The apartment is empt the rented furniture in place, all trace of HANNA gone. H looks round. He looks at the empty bath, the tap above it opens the kitchen cupboards - some coffee, sugar, that’s about it. He goes into the bedroom, the bed stripped bare lies down on the bed.  31. INT. HANNA’S APARTMENT. NIGHT MICHAEL lying on the bed, curled up, in his clothes, like foetus, asleep.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: The family at breakfast. MICHAEL slips quietly in the mai door, trying to go to his room without being heard. EMILY runs to look.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: It’s him. Sheepishly MICHAEL appears.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Where were you last night? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I stayed at a friend’s.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Carla. PETER looks. He seems to know exactly what’s been going o

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Get the boy something to eat. I think we all knew you’d come back to us eventually.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWIMMING LAKE. DUSK
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is alone in the deserted pool. He is on the jetty takes off his clothes and slips into the water. Just his head, like a seal’s, at one end, just out of the water, q still.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURTHOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: 1995. MICHAEL sitting alone, thinking back.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWIMMING LAKE. DUSK
dialogues.text: 1958. The sun slants, and for a few seconds the water dazzles. He slips his head under.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURTHOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: 1995. MICHAEL still sitting thoughtfully by himself in th empty court. Then he looks up. An ASSISTANT has appeared.  32.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Mr Berg. It is eight o’clock. Your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BRASSERIE. BERLIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: JULIA is already at the table in a chic modern brasserie. is a sympathetic young woman of around 23. MICHAEL approaches. When she sees him, she gets up.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I was early. MICHAEL leans in and kisses her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Julia. They’re uneasy. She looks a moment, then they sit down.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Welcome back.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RESTAURANT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Later. They have eaten. They both have big glasses of red wine. It’s more relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: So how will you decide?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’m happy back in Berlin, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You've seen your mother? JULIA nods.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I wanted to get away. There was nothing more to it. It was Paris, but it could have been anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Away from your parents?  33. JULIA doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m aware I was difficult. I wasn’t always open with you. I’m not open with anyone.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I knew you were distant. I'd always assumed it was my fault.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Julia. How wrong can you be? JULIA colours, on the verge of tears. Then she looks away

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: They drive through the gleaming streets. It’s been rainin Berlin is glistening. Their voices :

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I admit it now, I was nervous.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I was nervous too. It’s silly isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It is silly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Thank you for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’ll see you very soon.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL lets JULIA out, and is watching her safely to her door from the car.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Good night, Dad. MICHAEL suddenly gets out himself.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Julia, wait. I want to ask you a favour.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What favour?  34.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I want to take you on a trip. I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, maybe. Can I pick you up in the car? JULIA doesn’t need to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: At ten, say. JULIA smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Then good. MICHAEL hugs her, his heart aching with love. JULIA goes to her place. MICHAEL is left standing still in the plaza outside, not moving. Underneath the sound of what follows thirty years previously.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LECTURE ROOM. HEIDELBERG LAW SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: 1966. A WOMAN LECTURER has a class of about 75 STUDENTS. their hair, their dress, it could only be the 1960s.

dialogues.speaker: LECTURER
dialogues.text: Those of you for the special seminar group on The Legal System in the Third Reich, please stay on in this room. Professor Rohl will be here in a moment. Nearly all the STUDENTS leave, talking among themselves. eight are left, dotted around the huge room. MICHAEL is o of them, now 22, in a corduroy jacket and tie. There is a lull. MICHAEL looks round at the group of oddballs, then finds ROHL, distinguished, greying, is already in front o them.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Well, we seem to be quite a small group. A small group and a select one. Clearly, this is going to be a unique seminar. Let me start by thanking those of you who’ve chosen to take part. Good for you. A reading list, gentlemen. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL (cont'd) Karl Jaspers, The Question of German Guilt... A calm STUDENT with long hair smiles at MICHAEL. She look like Francoise Hardy. She murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHE
dialogues.text: And ladies.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDENT DIGS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is working alone at his desk, a light on. The doo his extremely modest student digs is open. MARTHE appears the door, silently. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHE
dialogues.text: So this is where you are.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Come in. But neither of them move. MARTHE just smiles from the doo

dialogues.speaker: MARTHE
dialogues.text: You take work seriously.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHE
dialogues.text: You’re rather a serious boy. MARTHE shrugs slightly.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s how I was brought up. What about you? Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHE
dialogues.text: You’re sure you want to work tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Well I do. But I won’t work every night.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHE
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow. They smile at one another. She goes.  36.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: The seminar group, long-haired, hippyish, is on the train PROFESSOR ROHL, with MARTHE, DIETER and a few others. MIC catches MARTHA’S eye. They smile. Then he opens the windo cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOWN HALL. MANNHEIM. DAY
dialogues.text: The STUDENTS are having a cigarette in front of the huge building. Two black vans with barred windows come by, carrying prisoners. The first one veers close to MICHAEL the pavement, then disappears into the inner courtyard. R smiles at MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Why all the police?

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: They’re worried about demonstrators.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: For or against?

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Both.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TOWN HALL. DAY
dialogues.text: A courtroom has been improvised inside the town hall. The are large windows, with milky glass, down the left-hand s As ROHL and the STUDENTS arrive, the court is a melee of PHOTOGRAPHERS, LAWYERS and PUBLIC. The three JUDGES are already in place, next to six selected CITIZENS. MICHAEL the others take places in the gallery

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: All photographers are now asked to leave. The PHOTOGRAPHERS go.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: The defendants, please. From being noisy and chaotic, the court is now silent.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: The first thing I’m going to do is hear motions from each of the defendants’ lawyers. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE (cont'd) They’re going to be arguing that there’s no reason to keep the defendants in jail until the outcome of the forthcoming trial. DIETER grins at MICHAEL in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I am going to take these cases one by one. MICHAEL is leaning down to get stuff out of his briefcase MARTHE shakes a pen which isn’t working.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Do you want a pen?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHE
dialogues.text: I’ve got a pen. So MICHAEL doesn’t hear as the JUDGE speaks.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Hanna Schmitz. There is a row of six DEFENDANTS. The fifth woman is HANN her hair tied in a knot, her gaze fixedly into the middle distance, not looking towards the SPECTATORS. She is wear a grey dress with short sleeves. They all sit, sideways t the gallery. HANNA rises to her feet. The words seem to c very quietly, across a great distance.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Your name is Hanna Schmitz?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes. It is only when the JUDGE repeats the name that MICHAEL l up, hearing it for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Can you speak louder please?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: My name is Hanna Schmitz. MICHAEL is rigid, blank, just staring.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Thank you. You were born on October 21st, 1922?  38.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: At Hermannstadt. And you’re now 43 years old?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: You joined the SS in 1943?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: What was your reason? What was your reason for joining? HANNA doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: You were working at the Siemens factory at the time?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: You'd recently been offered a promotion. Why did you prefer to join the Ss? HANNA has a DEFENCE COUNSEL, a young man, beside her, who about to get up. But the JUDGE forestalls him.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I’ll re-phrase my question. I’m trying to ascertain if she joined the SS freely. Of her own free will. Everyone waits.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I heard there were jobs.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Go on.  39.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I was working at Siemens when I heard the SS was recruiting.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Did you know the kind of work you'd be expected to do?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: They were looking for guards. I applied for a job. MICHAEL is intent now, so are the STUDENTS beside him.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: And you worked first at Auschwitz?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Until 1944. Then you were moved to a smaller camp near Cracow?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes. ROHL leans into MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Are you OK?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: You then helped move the prisoners west in the winter of 1944 in the so-called death marches?

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is hanging out of the window of the train, smokin cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL sits down in his seat. ROHL moves to sit opposite him.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: So what did you think?  40.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It wasn’t quite what I expecting.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Wasn’t it? In what way? What were you expecting? ROHL is looking at him. MICHAEL doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: I thought it was exciting.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Exciting?

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Why? Why did you think it exciting?

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Because it’s justice.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRYSIDE. DAY
dialogues.text: The train hurtles through the German countryside.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDENT DIGS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A student party, in a candle-lit room. MARTHE is singing guitar. It’s been going on for hours - the STUDENTS are o the floor with beer and cigarettes. The front door is ope DIETER, beer in hand, looks out to the balcony where he c see MICHAEL bent away from them, all by himself.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STUDENT DIGS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MICHAEL, his arms on the balcony, is smoking, looking out into the night. His eye lands on a student room in which couple are making love.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LECTURE ROOM. HEIDELBERG LAW SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: The small STUDENT GROUP is now rattling around informally the big lecture room.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: I need to correct an impression. Dieter said yesterday this was about justice. But is it? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL (cont'd) If it were about justice you might ask why has it taken so long? The war ended twenty years ago. Remember, there’ve been no significant trials between Nuremburg in 1946 and the Auschwitz trials a couple of years ago. That’s a long gap. What’s the reason for the gap? ROHL waits a moment for a STUDENT to answer.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: I’d have thought it was obvious.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Say.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Cowardice. It’s cowardice, isn’t it? It’s bad conscience. It’s the big cover-up.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: After the war. The German people didn’t want to look at what they’d done.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Because they had too much to hide. All our parents are liars. All right, mine are. So it’s left to us, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Because we're not implicated.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Aren’t you? Good. So that’s all right then. Everyone laughs.  42.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHE
dialogues.text: No, but seriously, Dieter’s right. My parents, I can’t even talk to them. I don’t love them. How could I? How could anyone love them? Because they’ve told themselves so many lies, they can’t remember the truth, let alone admit it. Isn’t that why we signed up for this seminar?

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHE
dialogues.text: Speaking for myself.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Michael?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m not sure any more. ROHL is staring at him thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: What did your father do, Dieter?

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: If you want to know, he was in the Waffen SS. There are some smiles, but DIETER rides over the reaction

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: That’s what I mean, that’s what I’m saying. So were a million other Germans.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: That’s exactly my point. That’s why it’s better not to pretend this is about justice. Forgive me, nor is it about getting into an emotional state. It has no purpose if it’s just the young giving their parents a bad time. There’s a silence. That’s clearly why some of them are th

dialogues.speaker: MARTHE
dialogues.text: So what is it about? What do you think?  43.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Societies think they operate by something called morality. But they don’t. They operate by something called law. You’re not guilty of anything merely by working at Auschwitz. 8,000 people worked at Auschwitz. Precisely 19 have been convicted, and only 6 for murder. To prove murder you have to prove intent. That’s the law. Remember, the question is never ‘Was it wrong?’ but ‘Was it legal?’ And not by our laws, no, by the laws at the time. DIETER frowns, unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: But isn’t that...

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Narrow?

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Yes. The law is narrow. ROHL looks unapologetic.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: On the other hand, I suspect people who kill other people tend to be aware that it’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURTROOM. MANNHEIM. DAY
dialogues.text: ROHL is leaning forward, attentive. HANNA is standing, opposite the JUDGE, who holds up a book called MOTHER & DAUGHTER : A STORY OF SURVIVAL.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Miss Schmitz, you're familiar with this book...

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Parts of it have already been read out in court. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE (cont'd) It’s an American publication, which has been translated. It’s by a survivor, a prisoner who survived, Ilana Mather...

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes I know. I know Ilana Mather.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: She was in the camp, wasn’t she, when she was a child? She was with her mother. The judge waits. HANNA seems arrogant, defiant.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: In the book, she describes a selection process. At the end of the month’s labour, every month, sixty inmates were selected. They were picked out to be sent from the satellite camp back to Auschwitz. That’s right, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s right.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: And so far, each of your fellow defendants has specifically denied being part of that process. Now I’m going to ask you. Were you part of it?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes. There is a stir among the other DEFENDANTS and in the cou They start talking to their LAWYERS.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: So you helped make the selection?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: You admit that? Then tell me, how did that selection happen? HANNA shrugs slightly, as though it were obvious.  45.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: There were six guards, so we decided we'd choose ten people each. That's how we did it - every month. We’d all choose ten.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Are you saying your fellow defendants took part in the process?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: We all did.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Even though they’ve denied it? But you admit it. You’re saying you took part in the process. The other DEFENDANTS stir with animosity, but the JUDGE i intent, following his own line. He waits.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Did you not realise you were sending these women to their deaths? HANNA nods slightly.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Yes but there were new arrivals, new women were arriving all the time, so of course we had to move some of the old ones on.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure you understand...

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: We couldn’t keep everyone. There wasn’t room. The JUDGE frowns, genuinely surprised that she doesn’t se to understand his point.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: No, but what I’m saying : let me rephrase : to make room, you were picking women out and saying ‘You you and you have to be sent back to be killed.’  46.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Well, what would you have done? HANNA is looking at the JUDGE - a perfectly straight question. MICHAEL smiles slightly, proud of her. Everyone the court waits for the JUDGE to answer. Silence. ROHL is impassive. But HANNA follows her own thoughts. She quietl asks herself a question.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: So should I never have signed up at Siemens?

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOBBY. TOWN HALL. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is alone, smoking. On a bench, side by side, are women. One is very small, dark, in her sixties. The other composed, formidable, elegant, in her thirties. ROSE and ILANA MATHER. They look up, catching MICHAEL’s eye. Then CLERK leans in to the younger woman.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Ms. Mather, they’re ready for you now. The two women go into the court. The door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is alone in the now-deserted lobby, unwilling to back. Then he goes to the door. He opens it a little. The sound of the trial. He opens the door fully. MICHAEL can that it is ILANA who is testifying. The court is conspicuously packed. Large black-and-white photographs o the labour camp now dominate the room. MICHAEL comes quie into the back of the room as the trial goes on. MICHAEL has pushed past a couple of people to sit down ne ROSE who is sitting in the body of the court. He looks ac to the DEFENDANTS. RITA BECKHART, a large older woman, is of a couple who isn’t bothering to listen.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: In your book you describe the process of selection...

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Yes. You were made to work and then, when you were no longer any use to them, then they sent you back to Auschwitz to be killed.  47.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: Are there people here today who made that selection?

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: I need you to identify them. Can you please point them out? ILANA points with her finger at the DEFENDANTS.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Her. And her. And her. And her. And her. And her. The last finger has been to HANNA. MICHAEL watches, but H does not react.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Each of the guards would choose a certain number of women. Hanna Schmitz chose differently.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: In what way differently?

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: She had favourites. Girls, mostly young. We all remarked on it, she gave them food and places to sleep. In the evening, she asked them to join her. We all thought - well, you can imagine what we thought. HANNA stares back, impassive. MICHAEL watches.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Then we found out - she was making these women read aloud to her. They were reading to her. At first we thought this guard, this guard is more sensitive, she's more human, she's kinder. Often she chose the weak, the sick, she picked them out, she seemed to be protecting them almost. But then she dispatched them. Is that kinder? HANNA looks back, not apologizing.  48.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOBBY. TOWN HALL. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL sits alone, head in hands, in despair.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURTROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Now ROSE is testifying. The court is quiet, focused.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I want to move on now to the march. As I understand it, you and your daughter were marched for many months.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes. It was the winter of 1944. Our camp was closed down, we were told we had to move on. But the plan kept changing every day. Women were dying all around us in the snow. Half of us died on the march. My daughter says in the book, less a death march, more a death gallop. MICHAEL looks along the row to where ILANA is now sitting

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Please tell us about the night in the church. MICHAEL watches as ROSE looks across to ILANA. ILANA star back at her. MICHAEL watches the exchange as ROSE nods, a accepting she must go ahead and speak.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: That night we actually thought we were lucky because we had a roof over our heads. We’d arrived ina village, as always, the guards took the best quarters, they took the priest’s house. But they let us sleep in a church. There was a bombing raid. In the middle of the night. At first we could only hear the fire, it was in the steeple. Then we could see burning beams, and they began to crash to the floor. Everyone rushed, rushed to the doors. But the doors had been locked on the outside.  49.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: The church burned down? Nobody came to open the doors? Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Even though you were all burning to death? ROSE nods.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: How many people were killed?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Everyone was killed.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: How did you survive?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I needed to get away from the other women. Because they were panicking, they were screaming. I couldn't stand it. I couldn’t stand their screaming. I was more frightened of the other women than I was of the fire. So I too my daughter and led her to the upper floor. I can’t defend what I did. It’s impossible to defend. I took Ilana in my arms and I led her towards the fire. There was a small gallery at the side of the church on the upper level. It saved our lives. The gallery didn’t burn. ROSE turns, in tears, to look at ILANA.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Thank you. I want to thank you for coming to this country today to testify.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LECTURE ROOM. LAW SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: The group is back in the big hall. But the atmosphere is grim. It’s a while before DIETER speaks.  50.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I don’t know what we're doing any more.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: You keep telling us to think like lawyers, but there’s something disgusting about this. ROHL is very still, like an analyst who is finally leadin his patient to the heart of things.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: This didn’t happen to the Germans. It happened to the Jews. Everyone is shocked at his violent passion.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: What are we trying to do?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: We're trying to understand.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Six women locked three hundred Jews in a church, and let them burn. What is there to understand? Tell me, I’m asking : what is there to understand? MICHAEL can’t answer. DIETER gets up, outraged now.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: I started out believing in this trial, I thought it was great, now I think it’s just a diversion.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Yes? Diversion from what?

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: You choose six women, you put them on trial, you say ‘They were the evil ones, they were the guilty ones’. Brilliant! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIETER (cont'd) Because one of the victims happened to write a book! That’s why they’re on trial and nobody else. Do you know how many camps there were in Europe? DIETER turns, furious.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: People go on about how much did everyone know? ‘Who knew?’ ‘What did they know?’ That isn’t the question. The question is ‘How could you let it happen?’ And - better - ‘Why didn’t you kill yourself when you found out?’ One of the group walks out.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Thousands! That’s how many. There were thousands of camps. Everyone knew. DIETER’S passion is so great that everyone is shaken.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Look at that woman...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Which woman?

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: The woman you’re always staring at. I’m sorry but you are. MICHAEL is white. The atmosphere is electric.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know which woman you mean.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: You know what I’d do? Put the gun in my hand, I’d shoot her myself.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. EMPTY ROAD. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL walks along an empty wooded road, miles from anywhere. The sun is shining through the trees behind him  52.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STRUTHOF CAMP. DAY
dialogues.text: The wire fence of a concentration camp, deserted. MICHAEL with a back-pack, goes alone through the metal gate. MICH walks among the deserted empty huts.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STRUTHOF CAMP. DAY
dialogues.text: Inside one of the huts, MICHAEL is by himself staring at line of empty beds. He moves on, overwhelmed, lost. He pa through the showers. Then he comes to a room with vast me cages on either side. In the cages, the countless dusty s of the exterminated.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STRUTHOF CAMP. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL opens a door and walks into a room with a line of ovens. He walks past them. Then he stands beside them, hi head down.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURTROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA is standing being examined by the JUDGE. Large photographs and maps of the village, with the lay-out of church, are now on display.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Why did you not unlock the doors? He waits. HANNA doesn’t reply.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Why did you not unlock the doors? The JUDGE turns to the row of DEFENDANTS.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I’ve asked all of you and I’m getting no answer. Two of the victims are in this court. They deserve an answer. ILANA and ROSE are not far away from MICHAEL and the STUDENTS. The JUDGE puts down a bound handwritten documen

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Here, this is the SS report. You all have copies. There is a flurry of paperwork among the DEFENDANTS and LAWYERS as they turn to their copies.  53.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: This is the report which was written, approved and signed by all of you immediately after the event. In the written report, you all claim you didn’t even know about the fire until after it happened. But that isn’t true, is it? The JUDGE waits.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Well? It isn’t true.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re asking.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: The first thing I’m asking is, why didn’t you unlock the doors? HANNA takes a look to the other DEFENDANTS. For the first time her poise is crumbling.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Obviously. For the obvious reason. We couldn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Why? Why couldn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: We were guards. Our job was to guard the prisoners. We couldn’t just let them escape.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I see. And if they escaped, then you'd be blamed, you’d be charged, you might even be executed?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Well then? The JUDGE waits.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: If we opened the doors, then there would have been chaos. How could we have restored order? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA (cont'd) It happened so fast. It was snowing. The bombs - There were flames all over the village. Then the screaming began. It got worse and worse. And if they’d all come rushing out, we couldn’t just let them escape. We couldn’t. We were responsible for them.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: So you did know what was happening? You did know? You made a choice. You let them die rather than risk letting them escape. HANNA can’t answer - she has no answer.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: The other defendants have made an allegation against you. Have you heard this allegation? HANNA does not reply.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: They say you were in charge.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: It isn’t true. I was just one of the guards. The other DEFENDANTS interrupt to call out ‘She was in charge’.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Did you write the report?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: No. No. We all discussed what to say. We all wrote it together.

dialogues.speaker: BECKHART
dialogues.text: She wrote it! She wrote the report. She was in charge.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: No. And I didn’t write the report. Does it matter who did? RITA BECKHART has called out from her place. The JUDGE lo at HANNA a moment.  55.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I need to see a sample of your handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: My handwriting?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Yes. I need to establish who wrote the report. At once HANNA’S COUNSEL rises.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA'S COUNSEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but I really don’t see how that’s appropriate. Nearly twenty years have gone by.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Somebody take her this piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA'S COUNSEL
dialogues.text: Are you really going to compare handwriting of twenty years ago, with handwriting of today?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Give her the paper. Counsel, approach the bench. A piece of paper and a pen are put down in front of HANNA Her COUNSEL moves to the bench. MICHAEL stares, first at then at the pen and paper, an apprehension rising in him.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: MICHAEL thinks back, to HANNA in her bedroom saying ‘No y read’, to her looking puzzled at the menu on the bicycle trip, and to her throwing a book away in the apartment. A this moment, MICHAEL realises she is illiterate.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURTROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Back in the courtroom, HANNA looks up to the JUDGE to sto the conference.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: There’s no need. I wrote the report.  56. MICHAEL, in a panic, pushes along his row, past ROHL and others, who all look up, knowing something is going on. H turns, as if sensing him behind her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STAIRS. HEIDELBERG LAW SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is sitting on the steps outside the lecture room. ROHL walks straight past him.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: You’ve been skipping seminars.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LECTURE ROOM. HEIDELBERG LAW SCHOOL. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL comes into the room and sits down, smoking a cigarette. ROHL waits.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: So? MICHAEL looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I have a piece of information. Concerning one of the defendants. Something they’re not admitting.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: What information? MICHAEL stubs out his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: You don’t need me to tell you. It’s perfectly clear you have a moral obligation to disclose it to the court.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It happens this information is favourable to the defendant. It can help her case. It may even affect the outcome, certainly the sentencing.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: There’s a problem. The defendant herself is determined to keep this information secret.  57. Two STUDENTS come in for the seminar.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: A moment, please. Please. Chastened, they leave.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: What are her reasons?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Because she’s ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Ashamed? Ashamed of what? MICHAEL doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Have you spoken to her?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: Why of course not?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I can’t. I can’t do that. I can’t talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: What we feel isn’t important. It’s utterly unimportant. The only question is what we do. ROHL gets up.

dialogues.speaker: ROHL
dialogues.text: If people like you don’t learn from what happened to people like me, then what the hell is the point of anything?

dialogues.speaker: INT. REMAND CELL. EVE
dialogues.text: HANNA is sitting on the edge of her bed. A GUARD comes to door.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: You have a visitor. Michael Berg. HANNA is taken aback for a moment. Then she gets up.  58.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRISON WAITING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is standing smoking a cigarette in the waiting ar A whole number of visitors, old people, children, familie are waiting. Some kids are playing with a football. Then GUARD arrives and calls out names. MICHAEL’s name is call

dialogues.speaker: INT. MEETING ROOM. PRISON. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA is led swiftly down a prison corridor towards her meeting and sat down at a desk to wait.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRISON YARD. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is led in the GROUP towards the visiting room. It come on to snow. As he walks towards the room, he loses heart. He changes his mind. The rest of the GROUP go on, he falls behind, watching them go. He begins to turn back INT. MEETING ROOM. PRISON. DAY. HANNA sits down at the empty table, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRISON YARD. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL turns away and heads back the way he came.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MEETING ROOM. PRISON. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA looks round. Nobody is coming. She waits more.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Time’s up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRISON. EVE
dialogues.text: HANNA is still waiting. Then she is led back to her cell. INT. MARTHE’S ROOM. STUDENT DIGS. NIGHT MICHAEL appears at the door of MARTHE’S room. She is work at her desk. He smiles and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHE
dialogues.text: You’ve taken your time. They kiss. She starts to pull his clothes off. He lets he He makes no move to undress her. She takes all his clothe off until he is naked, and she remains clothed. He looks her a moment, then takes her in his arms and they go down the bed. They make love.  59. INT. MARTHE’S ROOM. NIGHT MARTHE is apparently asleep, MICHAEL awake. As quietly as can MICHAEL tries to slip away.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I need to sleep by myself.

dialogues.speaker: INT. REMAND CELL. DAWN
dialogues.text: HANNA is standing naked at the sink, preparing herself fo the day. INT. STUDENT DIGS. MICHAEL’S ROOM. DAWN MICHAEL is lying in his own bed, staring up at the ceilin not able to sleep. MICHAEL reluctantly pushes back the co and gets naked out of bed. Slowly he begins to dress.

dialogues.speaker: INT. REMAND CELL. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA washes herself, naked.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDENT DIGS. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is dressed now. He stands in front of his mirror, adjusting his tie.

dialogues.speaker: INT. REMAND CELL. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA stands in front of the mirror, tying her tie. There a small, inadequate mirror in which she checks her dress black suit, a white blouse and black tie. She looks very formal.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRISON. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA is led through the prison by a GUARD.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOWN HALL. DAY
dialogues.text: A lot of people heading into the courtroom. As the semina group goes in, MICHAEL hangs back. ROHL looks at him as h goes through the doors. MICHAEL is left outside, then goe watch as the vans arrive.  60.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURTROOM. TOWN HALL. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA and the PRISONERS are led into the court. HANNA’S s is so formal that members of the public call out. ‘Nazi! Nazi!’ DIETER leans in to MARTHE. HANNA walks on to her place.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COURTROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Everyone rises as the JUDGES come in to take their places HANNA’s face is resigned, without expression. The JUDGES The whole court goes quiet.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: The court finds guilty the defendants Rita Beckhart, Karolina Steinhof, Regina Kreutz, Angela Zieber, Andrea Luhmann jointly aiding and abetting murder in three hundred cases. The court finds the defendant Hanna Schmitz guilty of murder in three hundred cases. There are tears in MICHAEL’s eyes as he watches.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: The court sentences the accused as follows. Rita Beckhart, Karolina Steinhof, Regina Kreutz, Angela Zieber, and Andrea Luhmann, you will each serve a total sentence in prison of four years and three months. ROHL, MARTHE, DIETER and the students are looking down on sentencing. MICHAEL is crying.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Hanna Schmitz, in view of your own admissions and your special role, you are in a different category. The court sentences the accused Schmitz to imprisonment for life. HANNA is impassive, not reacting. Then she turns and look to the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COURTHOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL walks away through the cameras and news crews.  61.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL sits on the train, thinking. The younger MICHAEL becomes the older.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: 1976. MICHAEL is sitting beside JULIA. MICHAEL is 32, JUL is a bright little 4 year-old in a coat. The countryside speeding by.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I said : I'll tell you when we get there. You told me you liked surprises.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I like surprises.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BLUMENSTRASSE. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL walks with JULIA towards their old house. He look round, the memory of coming with HANNA as a sick boy 18 y earlier clear in his mind. The same landmarks.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM. BERG APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: They are all three eating at the dinner table, eating a s roast chicken.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: She’s grown, hasn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It’s so long since I saw her, Michael, how can I tell?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: My fault. We shouldn’t have come unannounced.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Daddy, why’s she angry? MICHAEL smiles. Even CARLA smiles slightly.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m afraid I’ve have some bad news. Julia knows. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL (cont'd) We've already told her. Gertrud and I are getting a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Daddy’s going to live in his own house.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: You didn’t come for your father’s funeral, but you come for this?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You know, it’s not easy for me to visit this town.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Were you really so unhappy?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: That’s not what I’m saying. It’s not what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Well then? CARLA looks at him hard.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You mustn’t worry about Gertrud. I’m going to look after her. And anyway, let’s face it, she’s already a state prosecutor, she earns far more than I do.

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Michael, I’m not worried about Gertrud. I’m worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN. EVE
dialogues.text: Exhausted by her day, JULIA is sleeping in MICHAEL’S arms looks down at her, full of love.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SCHONEBERG. BERLIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: On the other side of a busy Berlin street full of traffic MICHAEL holds JULIA’S hand, a loving father, to guide her across the street. INT. LANDING. GERTRUD’S APARTMENT. BERLIN. NIGHT GERTRUD has come to the door, a shrewd-looking intelligen woman, a little older than MICHAEL, very thin, in slacks a blouse. MICHAEL is standing outside with JULIA.  63.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Hello Mummy.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Hello beautiful. GERTRUD leans down and scoops JULIA up, kisses her. MICHA stands on the step, hovering.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I don’t ask you in?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don’t mind at all. I’ve a lot to do, in fact. It doesn’t look like it. He stands, not going.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I took her to see where I grew up.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: You went to the West? My God, what a trip.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: We went to say hello to granny.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Oh. Daddy took you to see Carla, did he?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: She was strange.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Come on, let’s see what’s on TV. GERTRUD gives JULIA her supper and puts her in front of t TV. Then she comes back to MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: I bet she was strange.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You could say.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: She always was. Why on earth did you decide to do that?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Impulse.  64. GERTRUD says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I suppose if I’m honest we went because I wanted to re-establish contact.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: With your mother? And did you succeed? They both smile.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Are you all right? He touches her arm.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Michael you’re meant to be an intelligent man. Don’t you know, it’s very hard to receive contact if you’re not willing to give it? GERTRUD looks level, not unkind.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUD
dialogues.text: Say goodbye to Julia.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Daddy. MICHAEL turns to say goodbye. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. KREUZBERG. NIGHT MICHAEL standing in the empty room. It’s eerily silent. H goes to his bookcase. He runs his fingers along the spine as HANNA once did. He takes out a paperback of the Odysse He looks at it a moment, then he starts to read to himsel

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: “Sing to me of the Man, Muse, the man of twists and turns Driven time and again off course, once he had plundered The hallowed heights of Troy... He sits back.  65. INT. HANNA’S CELL. DAWN HANNA is in her cell, folding her blanket. She is 53, a n austerity, a greyness about her. Her cell is modern, but without decoration.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRISON. CORRIDOR. DAY
dialogues.text: A GUARD comes along the corridor, calling out ‘Mail’. She leans into Hanna’s cell to tell her she has mail. HANNA i obviously surprised.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAIL ROOM. PRISON. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA reports to the mail room where she is given a big parcel, which she is told to open. Inside, a huge batch o casette tapes and a tape machine.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CELL. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA is opening the box, taking out the tapes. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. EVE MICHAEL gets out a tape machine.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CELL. DAY
dialogues.text: In her cell HANNA takes out the machine. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. EVE MICHAEL holds the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Testing. Testing. 1-2-3.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CELL. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA puts a cassette into the machine.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The Odyssey by Homer. In panic, she turns it off. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. EVE MICHAEL presses the recording button and speaks into the machine.  66.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: The Odyssey by Homer. “Sing to me of the Man, Muse, the man of twists and turns Driven time and again off course, once he had plundered The hallowed heights of Troy... Many cities of men he saw and learned their minds, Many pains he suffered, heartsick at the open sea, Fighting to save his life and bring his comrades home... INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT Later. MICHAEL is now walking up and down, in his shorts T-shirt, microphone in hand, still reading.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: “Ah, how shameless - the way these mortals blame the gods. From us alone, they say, come all their miseries...

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Middle of the night. MICHAEL is lying on his back, still reading.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: “Who are you? Where are you from? Your city? Your parents? I’m wonderstruck - you drank my drugs, you're not bewitched...”

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL takes a cassette and puts it into a white box. He writes on the side ODYSSEY 6. Then he reaches up to put i a shelf next to boxes separately marked ODYSSEY 1,2,3,4,5 Then he takes out a small notebook and cross-references t new tape in a handwritten list.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CELL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s dark. HANNA is lying on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Zeus from the very start, the thunder king Has hated the race of Atreus with a vengeance -— (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL'S VOICE (cont'd) His trustiest weapon women’s twisted wiles... HANNA smiles with pleasure at his reading.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: A montage of MICHAEL reading and HANNA listening. MICHAEL reading different books. He is animated now, excited. The are extracts from The Old Man and the Sea (Hemingway) ; Anatol (Schnitzler) ; The World of Yesterday (Zweig) and Doctor Zhivago (Pasternak). MICHAEL catching fire with excitement with what he is doing. HANNA collecting the ta from the mail room and organizing on her shelves - her library growing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CELL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: HANNA is lying in bed listening to a new tape.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: The Lady with the Little Dog, by Anton Chekhov. “The talk was that a new face had appeared on the promenade, a lady with a little dog...”

dialogues.speaker: EXT. EXERCISE YARD. PRISON. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA is walking round with other PRISONERS, in sequence. Suddenly she stops dead, an idea hitting her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRISON LIBRARY. DAY
dialogues.text: The library is right next to the mail room. HANNA walks p the mail room and goes to the library counter.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I want to take out a book.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: Which book?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Do you have The Lady with the Little Dog?

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Hanna Schmitz.  68. The LIBRARIAN goes to get it. HANNA stands, waiting and l at the stacks of books, for the first time seeing possibility.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CELL. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA is back in the cell. She puts down a new parcel and book. She puts the parcel to one side, then opens the boo She then winds back the tape which is already in the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The Lady with the Little Dog, a story by Anton Chekhov. The talk was... She turns off the tape. She runs her finger along the tit ‘The Lady with the Little Dog’. She gets down a small decorated metal tin, and takes a pencil from it. She star making the sounds. ‘The’, ‘the’, ‘the’... L, L, L, etc.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CELL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: HANNA is working now, circling the word ‘the’ each time i comes in the book. The book is covered in marks. EXT & INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. EVE 1981. MICHAEL is coming down a busy Kreuzberg street. He 37. He goes into his block. He opens the door : the place much more lived-in. He picks up his mail. Thumbing throug it, he sees a letter in childish handwriting. MICHAEL fro opening it and taking out a piece of paper. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. EVE MICHAEL is holding a letter. He looks down at the writing ‘Thanks for the latest, kid. I really liked it.’ He stare then puts it down and steps back stunned.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CELL. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA stands with a new package. She opens it excitedly. takes out tapes. She looks for writing, a letter. There i none. She turns the packing paper over and over, but ther nothing. She stands, desolate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA effortfully writing various letters - just a single message on each. The pen working agonizingly across the paper. First :  69.

dialogues.speaker: I WOULD LIKE MORE ROMANCE, LESS ADVENTURE
dialogues.text: Next:

dialogues.speaker: I AM NOT SURE WHAT KAFKA IS SAYING
dialogues.text: INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. BEDROOM. NIGHT MICHAEL continuing to read to her on the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA still writing.

dialogues.speaker: DO YOU STILL LIKE DICKENS
dialogues.text: Then finally, many attempts at the same sentence, written many times :

dialogues.speaker: DO YOU RECEIVE MY LETTERS
dialogues.text: INT. STUDY. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. DAY MICHAEL is reading the latest letter from HANNA. He looks it. “Do you receive my letters? Write to me, kid.” MICHAE opens a drawer in a file box on the floor. There is a sta of her letters inside. He puts the latest on top of the p and closes the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CELL. PRISON. DAY
dialogues.text: HANNA stands at her window, in despair. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. KREUZBERG. DAY 1988. MICHAEL, 44, is at his desk, with the phone in his hand, with a typed letter in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER, (VOICE ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: You’re Michael Berg?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER, (VOICE ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: You got my letter?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I have it here.

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: As I say, Hanna Schmitz is coming up for release very soon.  70. MICHAEL fingers the letter a moment. INT. BRENNER’S OFFICE. PRISON. DAY MS BRENNER is sitting at her desk in a simple, modern off

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER
dialogues.text: Hanna has been in prison for over twenty years. She has no family. She has no friends. You’re her only contact. And I’m told you don’t visit her. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. KREUZBERG. DAY MICHAEL is sitting quite still.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No. I don’t. INT. BRENNER’S OFFICE. DAY

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER
dialogues.text: When she gets out, she’s going to need a job. She’s going to need somewhere to live. You can’t imagine how frightening the modern world will seem to her. There is a silence.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m still here. INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. KREUZBERG. DAY

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER
dialogues.text: I have no-one else to ask. If you don’t take responsibility for her, then Hanna has no future at all.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s kind of you. Thank you for letting me know. MICHAEL puts the phone down. He looks as if he has just b handed a sentence. He gets up and stares at the wall whic now stacked with all the books he has read. Then he goes his balcony. EXT & INT. MICHAEL’S APARTMENT. KREUZBERG. DAY MICHAEL stands looking out over Berlin from his balcony.  71.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRISON. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL walks along the road by the prison wall, then goe the guichet to sign in.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRISON YARD. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is waiting in a small barred waiting area as MS BRENNER walks across the yard to open the gate and let MICHAEL in.

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER
dialogues.text: You’re Michael Berg?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER
dialogues.text: Louisa Brenner. We were expecting you earlier.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: MS BRENNER is walking MICHAEL up the steps towards the pr canteen. They pass GUARDS and INMATES.

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER
dialogues.text: I should warn you: for a long time Hanna held herself together. She was very purposeful. In the last few years she’s different. She’s let herself go.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CANTEEN. PRISON. DAY
dialogues.text: MS BRENNER leads MICHAEL to the door of the canteen.

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER
dialogues.text: They’re in the canteen. They’re just finishing lunch. MICHAEL sees an OLD WOMAN who is sitting at a table. Her dress is stretched too tight across her heavy body. Her h is grey. She has a book in her lap, but she’s not reading A few PRISONERS are finishing their meal. It takes MICHAEL a moment to realise the OLD WOMAN is HAN Then HANNA becomes aware of being watched. She turns and looks round. At once her face lights up.
