MICHAEL smiles b but as he approaches her, he fixes onto her inquiring loo and sees the light go out of her eyes, as if she has look at him and been disappointed. He sits down opposite her. smiles, weary.  72.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: You’ve grown up, kid. She takes his hand. There is a long silence, MICHAEL unab to think of anything to say. He withdraws his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’ve got a friend who's a tailor, he makes my suits. He’ll give you a job. And I’ve found you somewhere to live. It’s a nice place. Quite small but nice. I think you’1l like it.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you. There’s a moment’s silence.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: There are various social programmes, cultural stuff I can sign you up for. And there’s a public library very close. HANNA nods slightly.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You read a lot?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I prefer being read to. There is a short silence.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: That’s over now, isn’t it? MICHAEL doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Did you get married?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I did. Yes I did. We have a daughter. I’m not seeing as much of her as I would like. I’d like to see a great deal more of her. After a few moments, he concedes.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: The marriage didn’t last.  73. There is a silence.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Have you spent a lot of time thinking about the past?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: You mean, with you?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No. No, I didn’t mean with me.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Before the trial I never thought about the past. I never had to.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: And now? What do you feel now? HANNA looks a moment, a haunting look, searching him. There’s a

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter what I think. It doesn’t matter what I feel. The dead are still dead. silence.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I wasn’t sure what you’d learnt.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: I have learnt, kid. I’ve learnt to read. MICHAEL stares, devastated.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I‘1ll pick you up next week, OK?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: That sounds a good plan.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Good. Quietly, or shall we make a big fuss?

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Quietly.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: OK. Quietly.  74. They look at each other. The other PRISONERS have already gone. They stand up. She scans his face again, searching his thoughts. He takes her in his arms, a little awkward.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Take care, kid.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: You too. They walk side by side, back towards the door. Then by wa saying goodbye, she takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: See you next week. She stretches her arm out before she lets go of his hand, then vanishes inside. MICHAEL walks on alone.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRISON. EVE
dialogues.text: MICHAEL comes out of the main entrance. He stands a momen looking round at the evening. MICHAEL walks to his car. INT. HANNA’S ROOM. EVE The room is simple, a bedroom to one side, a bathroom to other. It is all furnished with simple functional furnitu The end of a hard day’s work. MICHAEL hangs a picture ove the desk - a landscape, reminiscent of where they once we cycling. The job is done. He looks round, grimly content.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CELL. DAWN
dialogues.text: HANNA is lying on her bed, fully dressed. She gets up and gets some books down from the shelf. She puts them, one b one, in a pile on the table. Then she takes off her shoes She stands up and climbs onto the pile of books on the ta Her bare feet on the books. Then she reaches up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: MICHAEL gets out of the car. He is carrying a bunch of flowers. He walks towards the prison. He leans in to the GUARD who is in a modern office.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRISON. DAY
dialogues.text: From the far end of the corridor, MICHAEL is seen sitting a bench. MS BRENNER comes out of her office and murmurs i his ear. MICHAEL is seen nodding, ashen.  75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them come together down the corridor. They sto the open door of the cell. The body has been removed. The books are still on the floor. MICHAEL goes in. A bare tab a chair, a bed, a closet, a toilet in the corner behind t door. There are shelves with books, an alarm clock, a stu bear, two mugs, instant coffee, tea tins.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: She didn’t pack. She never intended to leave. MS BRENNER looks at him in confirmation. MICHAEL looks at two lower shelves on which are ranged the tapes with the cassette machine. Above the bed are a series of cuttings, pictures torn fro magazines, showing meadows, hillsides, pasture, cherry tr One in particular : a burst of autumnal colours. MICHAEL kneels on the bed to look at them. There are quotations, articles, recipes, even sayings in HANNA’S childish handwriting : ‘Spring lets its blue banner flutter throug the air’ is one. Then he sees a newspaper photograph : th young MICHAEL BERG receiving a prize from the school principal. The headline ‘Michael Berg receives school literature prize.’ MS BRENNER reaches out for a tea tin from the shelf. Then sits next to MICHAEL on the bed, and takes out a folded s of paper from her suit pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER
dialogues.text: She left me a message, a sort of will. I’11 read out the bit that concerns you. MICHAEL looks at the effortful handwriting on the page.

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER
dialogues.text: “There is money in the old tea tin. Give it to Michael Berg. He should send it, alongside the 7,000 marks in the bank, to the daughter who wrote the book. It’s for her. She should decide what to do with it. And tell Michael I said hello. Tell him to get on with his life.” MS BRENNER looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MS BRENNER
dialogues.text: Do you want to see her?  76. MICHAEL shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BRIDGE. MANHATTAN. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL rides in a taxi into Manhattan. A view of the familiar skyline.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIFTH AVENUE. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL'S taxi comes up Fifth Avenue. It draws up outside expensive apartment block. MICHAEL gets out and goes in, Manhattan skyline opening up behind him. INT. LIVING ROOM. ILANA’S APARTMENT. DAY A superbly appointed space full of great and expensive ar MICHAEL has taken his coat off. ILANA MATHER appears, elegant, well-dressed - on the surface, the spirit of prosperous New York. She is now in her early fifties.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Ms Mather?

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Yes. You’re Michael Berg. I was expecting you.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: So you must tell me: what exactly brings you to the United States?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I was already here. I was at a conference in Boston.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: You're a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: I was intrigued by your letter but I can’t say I wholly understood it. You attended the trial?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Almost twenty years ago. I was a law student. I remember you, I remember your mother very clearly.  77.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: My mother died in Israel - a good many years ago.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. MICHAEL hesitates for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Go on, please.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Perhaps you heard. Hanna Schmitz recently died. She killed herself. ILANA shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: She was a friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: A kind of friend. It’s as simple as this. Hanna was illiterate for the greater part of her life.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Is that an explanation of her behaviour?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Or an excuse? MICHAEL shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No. No. She taught herself to read when she was in prison. I sent her tapes. She’d always liked being read to. ILANA shifts slightly.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Why don’t you start by being honest with me? At least start that way. What was the nature of your friendship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was young I had an affair with Hanna. ILANA looks at him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I can help you, Mr. Berg. Or rather, even if I could I’m not willing to.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I was almost sixteen when I took up with her. The affair only lasted a summer. But.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: But what? MICHAEL just looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: I see. And did Hanna Schmitz acknowledge the effect she’d had on your life? MICHAEL stares back, understood for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: She'd done much worse to other people. I’ve never told anyone.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: People ask all the time what I learned in the camps. But the camps weren’t therapy. What do you think these places were? Universities? We didn’t go there to learn. One becomes very clear about these things. ILANA looks at him, unrelenting.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: What are you asking for? Forgiveness for her? Or do you just want to feel better yourself? My advice, go to the theatre, if you want catharsis. Please. Go to literature. Don't go to the camps. Nothing comes out of the camps. Nothing. 78.  79. ILANA looks at him, unrelenting.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What she wanted...what she wanted was to leave you her money. I have with me.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: To do what?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: As you think fit. MICHAEL reaches for his briefcase. He takes out the laven tea-tin, which he sets down on the table in front of ILAN

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Here. ILANA lifts the tin.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: When I was a little girl, I hada tea-tin for my treasures. Not quite like this. It had Cyrillic lettering. I took it with me to the camp, but it got stolen.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What was in it?

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Oh. Sentimental things. A piece of hair from our dog. Some tickets to operas my father had taken me to. It wasn’t stolen for its contents. It was the tin itself which was valuable, what you could do with it. She sits a moment, overcome, her hand on the tin.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: There’s nothing I can do with this money. If I give it to anything associated with the extermination of the Jews, then to me it will seem like absolution and that is something I’m neither willing nor in a position to grant. MICHAEL nods slightly.  80.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I was thinking maybe an organization to encourage literacy.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Good. There’s a silence.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Do you know if there’s a Jewish organization?

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: I‘ll be surprised if there isn’t. There’s a Jewish organisation for everything. Not that illiteracy is a very Jewish problem. There is the shadow of a smile.

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: Why don’t you find out? Send them the money.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Shall I do it in Hanna’s name?

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: As you think fit. ILANA smiles slightly. She puts her hand on top of the ti

dialogues.speaker: ILANA
dialogues.text: I‘ll keep the tin. INT. ILANA’S HOUSE. DAY ILANA is standing at the window watching down to the stre where MICHAEL is walking away. She has the tin in her han When he’s vanished, she turns and goes into her bedroom. There on the dressing table, there is a framed photo of I with her mother in Germany before the war. She sets the t down beside the photo.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: 1995. MICHAEL is driving JULIA in the big Mercedes throug the German countryside. He is tense, silent. JULIA takes sideways look at him, but he does not respond.  81.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I thought you liked surprises.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I do. I do like surprises.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COUNTRY. DAY
dialogues.text: They draw up at a church. It is the same one he and HANNA passed on their bicycles years before. MICHAEL and JULIA out and walk towards the graveyard at the side.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CEMETERY. DAY
dialogues.text: MICHAEL & JULIA stand at a deserted grave-side. The whole cemetery is seen. MICHAEL stoops down and uncovers a simp stone : HANNA SCHMITZ 1923-1988. JULIA watching, says her name.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Hanna Schmitz. JULIA waits a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Who was she?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: That’s what I wanted to tell you. That’s why we're here. JULIA looks, waiting. MICHAEL looks for a moment as if he will not go on.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: So tell me. There is a moment, then they turn to stroll, MICHAEL talk starting to tell the story.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I was 15, I was coming home from school, I was ill... They walk away among the trees.
